awd_titl_txt: Planning: Advancing Discovery on a Sustainable National Research Enterprise
awd_abstract_narration:
This project develops a research framework to understand how research enterprise infrastructure enables the sustainable success of large, federally funded awards. Research enterprise infrastructure underpins every federally funded scientific research activity in academia. Limited, publicly accessible knowledge exists about how this infrastructure specifically facilitates the sustainable success of research initiatives. Moreover, turnover in the research administration workforce has resulted in the loss of institutional knowledge and best practices. These gaps make it difficult for research institutions, especially emerging research institutions, to evaluate lessons learned and emulate successes while developing research enterprise structures that best meet the needs of the communities they serve.
 
This planning project creates a “research on the research enterprise” framework to address the knowledge gap by: 1) identifying the research questions and output strategies that will best meet the nuanced needs of emerging and developing research institutions, 2) determining the appropriate methodologies to capture university research enterprise team and project leadership knowledge, and 3) establishing the partnerships and roles necessary for the success of the research design and development of a full-scale implementation project. Understanding how these elements can best serve emerging research institutions guides the identification of research questions, methodologies, and partnerships. The knowledge gaps addressed through this planning project will support the accelerated development of a national research infrastructure that is responsive to the nuanced needs of minority serving institutions (MSIs), non-R1 (e.g. R2-high research doctoral universities, D/PU-doctoral/professional universities), and baccalaureate/associate’s colleges and communities they serve. The increased capacity enabled through this work will help ensure that the advancement and application of science can better respond to the needs of the entire nation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA, THE

por.por_cntn:
This planning-phase effort developed the framework for a full research project that would understand how research enterprise infrastructure enables the sustainable success of large, federally funded awards. Research enterprise infrastructure makes nearly all academic research and research-adjacent activities possible in the United States. Knowledge about how specifically these complex infrastructures facilitate large scientific research projects is largely unanalyzed and unavailable to the public. This gap limits the sharing of institutional knowledge, lessons learned, and best practices, making it challenging for universities and colleges to tap into this understanding in support of developing and growing research enterprise infrastructures. This knowledge could be especially beneficial for institutions working to increase capacity in order to support large federally funded projects.

 

Outcomes from this work included:

 

1)    Identifying the research questions and output strategies that will best meet the nuanced needs of emerging and developing research institutions.

 

The planning phase specifically facilitated collaboration between researchers and research administrators to ensure that a full research project could be framed in a way that would capture the vast knowledge existing from both perspectives. Due to the high demand for the research a full-scale project would produce, it was determined that disseminating outcomes throughout the project rather than at its culmination would be critical. Both written and in-person dissemination across a variety of forums would be important to ensure the usability of results for researchers, research administrators, and institution leadership. In-person outreach would include co-locating a session at the Academic Data Science Alliance leadership conference; this would be an avenue to get formative feedback from a wide range of stakeholder institutions and disseminate our findings. 

 

2)    Determining the appropriate methodologies to capture university research enterprise team and project leadership knowledge

 

This project determined that multiple methodologies are needed to accomplish the goals of a full research project on this topic. This includes interviews, focus groups, surveys, and quantitative analysis of existing data where appropriate.

 

3)    Establishing the partnerships and roles necessary for the success of the research design and development of a full-scale implementation project.

 

Scoping the partnerships and participants represented a key focus area for this phase that drove the development of the entire research framework. These efforts helped the shaping of the parameters of the research framework so that a full-scale proposal could be set up to most effectively address areas of highest need. This led to a stronger emphasis on the role of project sustainability throughout the pre-award and post-award phases.
